2.text: Hi, everyone! Welcome back to another episode of TJLC explained.

5.text: My name is Rebekah and Happy Valentine's Day!

8.text: What better way to celebrate this holiday of romantic love than settling in with a cheesy romantic comedy

13.text: and enjoying the evening to yourself or with a romantic partner.

17.text: That's right. Today I'm going to be talking to you about the unaired pilot.

21.text: The pilot has been a gem in the fandom since it was first released on the DVD.

27.text: people watching the pilot couldn't help but notice the tonal differences of this episode.

34.text: I think the reason a lot of people write off this episode is

37.text: because they compare this version to the finalized version that was eventually released.

41.text: And they dismissed the more overt subtext in the pilot as an accident

44.text: that the writers were trying to correct in the finished version.

46.text: Even going by that argument, the producers failed.

48.text: But you have to understand that going into it, no one in the production crew knew

51.text: that they were going to be remaking the show from the ground up.

54.text: Everyone involved thought this was the direction where the show was going.

56.text: The actors, set designers, and everyone else involved signed on for this corny,

60.text: low budget romance with an adventure thrown in.

62.text: The only reason it was redone at all is because the BBC was so thrilled with the idea

66.text: that they wanted to make it the kind of culturally iconic show

68.text: that their LGB research showed that LGBT audiences were craving.

72.text: So the budget was upped, the time and quality increased,

74.text: and the subtext was handled a lot more delicately.

77.text: But that was all after this version.

79.text: So I'm going to talk about this episode in isolation from the rest of the series.

82.text: Looking at it this way makes it a lot more easier

84.text: to see the writer's true intent in writing the episode,

86.text: rather than making it seem like some kind of bizarre fluke.

88.text: So without further ado, let's get into the unaired pilot.

91.text: Rebekah: Right off the bat, we're introduced to John,

93.text: who is having trouble sleeping and seems totally isolated.

96.text: He goes to therapy, but he seems pretty relaxed while he's there.

98.text: He writes off his therapist's blogging assignment because he has nothing to write about.

103.text: Rebekah: The episode also establishes early that Lestrade is the one in contact with Sherlock

107.text: and the rest of the Scotland Yarders don't seem overly thrilled at the idea of him being on the case.

111.text: There's also the lovely establishing shot of the statue with Cupid on it

115.text: with the title of the episode shown beneath.

117.text: Right after that John bumps into Mike Stamford.

119.text: They chat about where John is staying and John jokes that no one would want to live with him,

122.text: hinting that he might be slightly disagreeable himself. And we get this iconic exchange:

126.text: Who'd want me for a flatmate?

131.text: Well, you're the second person to say that to me today.

142.text: Rebekah: In his first scene Sherlock comes off as eccentric and a bit off-putting, but there's something,

146.text: I don't know, almost sexual about this introduction scene. I can't quite put my finger on it.

151.text: (Sherlock grunting from the effort of whipping)

156.text: Molly is interacting with Sherlock throughout this scene and it's pretty obvious

159.text: that she likes him, especially when she asks him out for coffee.

162.text: Sherlock's reactions to her show that he knows this, though, and he's pretty clearly not interested.

167.text: Are you wearing lipstick? You weren't wearing lipstick before.

169.text: I was wondering if you'd like to have coffee.

172.text: Black, two sugars please, I'll be upstairs.

175.text: He heads off to send some emails when Mike and John find him.

177.text: Sherlock needs to send a text and Mike conveniently left his phone in his other coat,

181.text: so John politely offers him his.

190.text: It's an old mate of mine - John Watson.

196.text: Rebekah: By the look on John's face he's pretty keen on the fact that Sherlock is as obviously talented as he is.

200.text: They're briefly interrupted by Molly coming back with Sherlock's coffee

203.text: and Sherlock giving her some blunt fashion advice.

210.text: Really? I thought it was a big improvement. Your mouth's too small now.

215.text: Both John and Sherlock are smiling and tossing quips back and forth.

218.text: Sherlock: Sorry, I've gotta dash, I think I left my riding crop in the mortuary.

223.text: We've just met and we're gonna go and look at a flat?

228.text: We don't know a thing about each other. I don't know your name, I don't even know where we're meeting.

232.text: Rebekah: Sherlock smiles to himself before delivering a string of deductions that leave John in quite a state.

237.text: I know you're an army doctor. And you've recently been invalided home from Afghanistan.

242.text: I know you've got a brother with a bit of money who's worried about you but you won't go to him for help

245.text: because you don't approve of him, possibly because he's an alcoholic.

248.text: More likely because he recently walked out on his wife.

252.text: And I know your therapist thinks your limp's psychosomatic, quite correctly I'm afraid.

257.text: It's enough to be going on with, don't you think?

262.text: The name's Sherlock Holmes and the address is 221B Baker Street. (wink) Afternoon.

269.text: Sherlock the next day is warm towards both John -

279.text: Rebekah: When they get upstairs, Sherlock tidies the flat a bit so John will stay.

282.text: He's also smiling and telling jokes.

286.text: Friend of mine. Well, I say friend...

289.text: All of this shows that while he's a bit out there, he really is human and wants people to like him.

293.text: That's when Mrs. Hudson comes back in.

295.text: What do you think, Dr. Watson? There's another bedroom upstairs... If you'll be needing two bedrooms.

300.text: Well, of course we'll be needing two.

302.text: Oh, don't worry, there's all sorts round here. Mrs. Turner next door's got married ones.

307.text: So, quick series of things here. The first person in the episode who knows Sherlock well thinks

311.text: he brought a man back to see the flat because they're dating.

314.text: Because she thinks Sherlock is gay. Sherlock says absolutely nothing to correct her

318.text: and while John seems a bit surprised, he doesn't seem that bothered at the assumption.

322.text: On another note, in the original stories, Doyle had a lot of continuity errors.

325.text: One of the most common were character names.

327.text: On a few occasions he referred to Mrs. Hudson as Mrs. Turner.

330.text: The writers themselves have said that this line is in reference to that continuity error.

333.text: So what is it implying that Mrs. Turner has a gay married couple living next door?

337.text: John admits looking Sherlock up online. Bit eager there, are we?

340.text: And still seems hesitant to believe what Sherlock can do despite seeing it firsthand.

343.text: You said you could identify a software designer by his tie and a retired plumber by his left hand.

349.text: Yes, and I can read your military career by your face and your leg

352.text: and your brother's drinking habits by your mobile phone.

359.text: But I know about his drinking habits, I even know that he left his wife.

363.text: Rebekah: Mrs. Hudson mentions the string of suicides the police have been investigating

366.text: just as Lestrade gets to Baker Street. Lestrade asks Sherlock to come investigate the case.

371.text: Brixton, Lauriston Gardens. Will you come?

380.text: Again, it's driving home that despite the fact they doesn't get on well with some people,

383.text: he really is lonely and wants people to like him.

386.text: (Still Rebekah) He gets excited about taking the case, though, and dashes off,

391.text: Look at him dashing. (laughs) My husband was just the same.

395.text: But you're more the sitting down type, I can tell.

398.text: I'll make you that cuppie, you rest your leg.

406.text: It's just that, sometimes, this bloody thing.

409.text: I understand dear, I've got a hip.

411.text: A cup of tea would be lovely, thank you.

412.text: Just this once dear, I'm not your housekeeper.

415.text: A couple of biscuits too, if you've got 'em.

419.text: Again, Sherlock isn't the only one around here who's a little bit unsociable.

422.text: It's pretty clear that despite his confusion with the situation, John wanted to join in on the adventure.

426.text: After all, he started the episode complaining that nothing every happened to him.

429.text: And here's something exciting happening right in front of him, apparently just out of reach. But it isn't.

433.text: Sherlock hears his outburst and comes back upstairs to proposition him.

437.text: You're a doctor. In fact you're an army doctor.

448.text: Seen a lot of injuries, then. Violent deaths.

453.text: Bit of trouble too, I bet.

454.text: Of course. Yes. Enough for a lifetime. Far too much.

460.text:
- Want to see some more?
- God, yes!

462.text: And the greatest partnership the world has ever seen is born.

465.text: And yes, there's the intense eye contact and the double entendre of John's excited exclamation at the end.

470.text: They aren't exactly being delicate with it.

471.text: Sherlock and John head off and Mrs. Hudson remarks that it's indecent

474.text: how excited Sherlock is to be running out to solve a crime with his new partner.

478.text: Remember that Oscar Wilde was charged with indecency in 1895?

481.text: Who cares about decent? The game, Mrs. Hudson, is on!

485.text: So they get a cab to the crime scene and at first Sherlock is sitting with his head awkwardly angled

489.text: in what looks to be an attempt to get John to notice his cheekbones.

492.text: I mean, seriously, who sits like this?

494.text: He does eventually break the silence, though, and answers John's questions

497.text: about where they're going and what he does.

500.text: Crime scene. There's been a murder. Next?

504.text: Who are you? What do you do?

506.text: Fff... I'd say private detective, but...

509.text: The police don't go to private detectives.

511.text: I'm a consulting detective. I'm the only one in the world. I invented the job.

516.text: It means when the police are out of their depths, which is always, they consult me.

520.text: But the police don't consult... amateurs.

524.text: John is hesitant to call Sherlock an amateur because he doesn't want to hurt his feelings.

527.text: In response Sherlock finally explains how he knew so much about John when they met.

530.text: When I met you for the first time yesterday and asked "Afghanistan or Iraq?" you looked surprised.

535.text:
- How did you know?
- I didn't know, I saw.

537.text: Tanned face but no tan above the wrists. You’ve been abroad, but not sunbathing.

541.text: Your haircut and the way you hold yourself says military.

543.text: Your conversation when you entered the room says trained at Bart's, so... army doctor, obvious.

547.text: Your limp’s really bad when you walk but you don’t ask for a chair when you stand, like you’ve forgotten about it.

553.text: That means the limp is at least partly psychosomatic.

555.text: That says the original circumstances of the injury were traumatising. Wounded in action, then.

560.text: So: where does an Army doctor get himself a suntan and wounded in action these days?

566.text: There's your brother. Your phone. It’s expensive, e-mail enabled, MP3 player.

572.text: You’re looking for a flatshare – you wouldn’t waste money on this. It’s a gift, then.

574.text: Scratches. Not just one, but many over time. It’s been in the same pocket as keys and coins.

578.text: The man sitting beside me wouldn’t treat his one luxury item like this.

581.text: It’s had a previous owner, then. The next bit’s easy. You know it already.

586.text: Harry Watson: clearly a family member who’s given you his old phone.

589.text: Not your father; this is a young man’s gadget. Could be a cousin,

592.text: but then you’re a war hero returning home who can’t find a place to live.

596.text: Unlikely you’ve got an extended family, certainly not one you’re close to, so brother it is.

604.text: Three kisses says it’s a romantic attachment. The expense of the phone says wife, not girlfriend.

608.text: You’re looking for cheap accommodation, but you won’t go to your brother for help.

611.text: That says you’ve got problems with him.

614.text: Maybe you liked his wife. Maybe you don't like his drinking.

618.text: How can you possibly know about the drinking?

620.text: Shot in the dark. Good one, though.

623.text: Power connection: tiny scuff marks around the edge of it.

626.text: Every night he plugs it in to recharge but his hands are shaking.

628.text: You never see those marks on a sober man’s phone; never see a drunk’s without them.

631.text: John's reaction is about what you'd expect at this point. As is Sherlock's.

645.text:
- You think so?
- Of course it was!

647.text: It was extraordinary! It was quite extraordinary!

651.text:
- Not what people usually say.
- What do they usually say?

655.text: It's interesting to know that Sherlock doesn't get everything, right?

661.text: Harry and me don't get on. Never have.

664.text: Harry and Clara are getting a divorce. Split up three months ago.

671.text: Spot on, then. I didn’t expect to be right about everything.

678.text: Now, what exactly am I supposed to be doing here?

680.text: No, seriously, why am I here?

684.text: Sherlock's first mistake in the series is assuming someone was straight.

686.text: I think the writers might be trying to tell us something.

689.text: So at the crime scene we're shown again

690.text: that people don't find Sherlock to be the most likeable person in the world.

693.text: But after the last scene we now know it's because of his abilities.

696.text: Sherlock isn't afraid to lash back, though, and uses his talents to shut Anderson up.

700.text: And is your wife away for long?

703.text: Oh, don’t pretend you worked that out. Someone told you that.

706.text: Sherlock: Your deodorant told me that.

710.text: Well, of course it's for men, I'm wearing it.

713.text: Rebekah: We get ready for the crime scene and Sherlock starts trying to get John involved in the process,

717.text: all the while making sarcastic quips.

725.text: I'm supposed to be helping you pay the rent.

726.text: Yeah, but this is more fun.

727.text: John does reprimand Sherlock for calling the situation fun, but Sherlock's response makes it clear

731.text: that he does care about the people in danger.

733.text: Fun? There's a woman lying dead.

734.text: No, there are two women and three men lying dead. Keep talking and there’ll be more.

737.text: John gives his best assessment of the corpse and Sherlock launches into his deductions.

741.text: John continues to compliment Sherlock throughout this and he still pretty visibly startles him.

751.text: Do you know you do that out loud?

756.text: You'll remember from the first episode that this is something from the original stories

759.text: but it's a bit more obvious seeing it play out on camera.

762.text: Sherlock eventually makes an important leap in the case and runs off after revealing the key clue.

767.text: Okay, so let's quickly talk about the title.

769.text: The first Sherlock Holmes story was called A Study in Scarlet.

771.text: In the show it's changed to A Study in Pink.

774.text: Now since the 1940's in Nazi Germany pink has been associated with homosexuality.

777.text: And the writers chose to change the title and make the color pretty important in the episode knowing this.

782.text: And they did it anyway. They could've left it Scarlet, but they made it Pink.

785.text: So after Sherlock leaves, everyone at the crime scene basically ignores John and tells him to leave.

789.text: Sally warns John off of Sherlock by saying he's dangerous.

792.text: You know why he's here? He's not paid or anything, he likes it. He gets off on it.

798.text: The weirder the crime the more he gets off and you know what?

801.text: One day just showing up isn't going to be enough.

803.text: One day we'll be standing round a body and Sherlock Holmes will be the one who put it there.

809.text: Because he's a psychopath and psychopaths get bored.

812.text: Rebekah: John more or less shakes it off, though, and before he finds a cab, happens to look up.

816.text: Now I need to be sure you're prepared for what's about to happen.

819.text: Just...it's going to be a lot. Okay. Roll the clip:

842.text: The jazzy saxophone, Sherlock's silhouette illuminating against the moonlight,

845.text: John's look of absolute adoration - cheesy, romantic, beautiful perfection. Ah!

850.text: John is miffed about being left behind, though, and goes back to his flat instead of Baker Street.

854.text: Sherlock, though, knows just how to lure him back in.

862.text: John leaves in about two seconds and is so keyed up on the way to Baker Street

866.text: that the driver actually comments on it. (laughs)

876.text: Sorry. You just look a bit... wired.

880.text: Wired? What do you mean, wired?

882.text: When he gets there, Sherlock at first makes it seem like he called him there for nothing,

885.text: which just makes John even more frustrated. He then starts to look like he might actually be the killer

889.text: like Sally implied, but he eventually explains what's going on.

893.text: Maybe she just dropped it in the back of his car, maybe she planted it on purpose to lead us to him,

896.text: but the murderer has her phone.

901.text: Rebekah: He invites John to come along on the rest of the case,

903.text: and John makes one last attempt to express his objections.

910.text: Said you get off on this, you enjoy it.

911.text: And I said danger, and here you are.

919.text: They do both get off on it. John knows it and Sherlock was right to call him out on it.

922.text: They head to the spot where they told the killer to meet them

924.text: and Sherlock explains why the killer would feel compelled to go there,

928.text: I love the brilliant ones. So desperate to get caught.

933.text: Appreciation. At long last a spotlight.

937.text: To you it's an arrest, to them it's a coming out party.

940.text: It's the frailty of genius. It needs an audience.

943.text: Yeah. Yes, I suppose it does.

947.text: I mean, I don't think I've ever heard that phrase used any other way but one, have you?

951.text: And John's response makes it pretty clear that they're talking about more than just the murderer here.

954.text: At the restaurant we meet Angelo, who is the next person who knows Sherlock,

957.text: likes him, and thinks he's gay.

959.text: Anything on the menu, whatever you want, free. (blows on his finger)

963.text: All on the house, you and your date.

966.text: Again, Sherlock does nothing to correct the assumption.

968.text: Even though John says it's not a date, Angelo does his best

971.text: to make Sherlock seem as attractive as possible.

973.text: Oh, uh, ohhhh, this man. He got me off a murder charge.

979.text: This is Angelo. Three years ago I successfully proved to Inspector Lestrade

982.text: that at the time of a particularly vicious triple murder,

984.text: Angelo was in a completely different part of town, car-jacking.

990.text: Sherlock tells John to order since they might be waiting a while, but doesn't seem to want to eat himself.

999.text: You haven’t eaten today? For God’s sake, you need to eat.

1001.text: No, you need to eat. I need to think. The brain’s what counts. Everything else is transport.

1005.text: This will be important in a minute.

1011.text: So, do you have a girlfriend to feed you up sometimes?

1017.text: That what girlfriends do? Feed you up?

1027.text: You don't have a girlfriend, then?

1039.text: Which is fine, by the way.

1043.text: So you don't have a boyfriend, then?

1052.text: That was pretty obvious he was asking about... and I'm not the only one who thinks so.

1056.text: John, you should know that I consider myself married to my work

1060.text: and, while I'm flattered by your interest, I'm really not looking for (John: No!) any kind of...

1064.text: No... I wasn't asking you out. No.

1068.text: I'm just saying, it's all fine.

1071.text: Whatever shakes your... boat. I'm gonna shut up now.

1076.text: I think that's for the best.

1077.text: Yeah, Sherlock, I don't believe him either.

1078.text: Also remember how blunt Sherlock was with Molly earlier?

1080.text: He didn't say anything on being flattered by her offer.

1083.text: But a cute army doctor on the other hand is a bit more appealing.

1085.text: John, in an absolute garbage move, keeps pressing the issue.

1097.text: I told you that line would come back. And yes, he did just ask Sherlock if he masturbates.

1101.text: No, I don't know what the possible platonic interpretation of that is. There isn't one!

1105.text: But throughout this conversation food and sex are used interchangeably.

1108.text: This will be important at the end of the episode. Now for one of the interviews I referenced last week,

1112.text: we know that Moffat thinks Sherlock is a volcano of sexual frustration waiting to erupt.

1116.text: Knowing that makes this next bit make more sense,

1118.text: because Sherlock was just propositioned, he turned him down, and he 'hasn't eaten' in days.

1122.text: He's tamping down everything as much as he can, but he can't control it entirely,

1125.text: so it comes on a bit strong when he explains who the killer is.

1128.text: There are cars that pass like ghosts, unseen, unremembered.

1134.text: There are people we trust, always, when we’re alone, when we’re lost, when we’re drunk.

1143.text: but every day we disappear into their cars and let the trap close around us.

1147.text: I give you the perfect murder weapon of the modern age,

1157.text: Sherlock goes after the killer when he does show up and warns John not to interfere.

1160.text: However, the situation quickly goes south and John instantly notices.

1165.text: Angelo: It's okay. All part of the plan.

1173.text: (Sherlock grunts as he's pushed into the car)

1174.text: Trouble is, your friends all think you’re acting.

1178.text: That's the thing about people, they’re all stupid.

1182.text: (Sherlock still struggling and groaning the whole time)

1187.text: No, no, no, no, no. All part of the plan. Sherlock always has a plan.

1193.text: He chases after the cab and leaves his cane behind.

1195.text: His concern for Sherlock was enough to cure him of his psychosomatic limp.

1198.text: Sherlock wakes up back in 221B with the cabbie being extremely creepy and predatory.

1204.text: That's right, you warm yourself up. I made everything nice and cosy for you.

1210.text: Now, now. Drug's still in your system.

1214.text: You'll be weak as a kitten for at least an hour.

1219.text: I could do anything I wanted to you right now, Mr. Holmes

1228.text: But don't worry, I'm only gonna kill you.

1230.text: Again, Sherlock is being repeatedly associated with homosexuality.

1234.text: With his lack of interest in women, with the people around him assuming he's gay,

1237.text: him shouting 'Pink!', him knowing having a boyfriend is fine.

1239.text: Him being sexualized by the camera here subconsciously does the same thing.

1242.text: This is because in film the camera's gaze stands in for the presumed male audience.

1246.text: So when the camera focuses on a male body the way it normally would on a female body,

1249.text: the audience, consciously or not, picks up on gay undertones.

1253.text: Again, these things on their own don't necessarily mean that Sherlock is gay,

1255.text: but the production crew definitely knows what this kind of camera shot implies,

1258.text: and on top of everything else it's painting a pretty clear picture.

1261.text: Sherlock is obviously completely vulnerable here and the audience sympathizes with that.

1264.text: We forget about his unsociableness earlier on and we want him to get out of the scene unharmed.

1268.text: The cabbie like a true villain starts monologuing

1270.text: and Sherlock even in his drugged state deduces his true motivation.

1273.text: You risked your life five times just to kill strangers.

1284.text: Aneurysm. Right in here. Any breath could be my last.

1291.text: Well, you have just murdered five people.

1296.text: I'm mostly pointing this out now so I can come back to it in a future video,

1299.text: but fans of the series will know how this line ends up being changed later on.

1302.text: As they're talking the police arrive and Sherlock realizes that must be

1305.text: cause John noticed something was wrong.

1307.text: Good old Doctor Watson. (phone still ringing)

1313.text: And he still is. At this point he thinks all John did was call the police.

1316.text: As Sherlock in his compromised state is eventually goaded into taking the pill,

1334.text: Outside Sherlock finally realizes who saved him as he describes the shooter.

1338.text: The bullet they just dug out of my wall was from a hand gun.

1341.text: A shot clean through the heart over that distance with that kind of a weapon

1344.text: – that’s a crack shot you’re looking for, but not just a marksman; a fighter.

1348.text: His hand couldn’t have shaken at all, so clearly he was acclimatised to violence.

1353.text: He didn’t fire until I was in immediate danger, though, so strong moral principles.

1358.text: You’re looking for a man probably with a history of military service, nerves of steel...

1370.text: Actually, do you know what? Um, ignore me.

1374.text: He knows he's underestimated John once again and he needs to get over to him as soon as he can.

1377.text: Before he can make it there Lestrade pulls him over to taunt him about the pills.

1380.text: Did you choose the right pill?

1383.text: I don't know. In all the confusion, I lost track. I don’t know which I chose.

1391.text: Multiple things at the end of this episode make it clear that Sherlock isn’t as above everyone else

1395.text: as he tried to make it seem earlier on. He’s human.

1398.text: Sherlock makes it over to John and lets him know that he figured it out.

1403.text: Don't, just don't. What did you do with the gun?

1406.text: Oh, uh, bottom of the Thames.

1416.text: I ran after the cab, called the police, of course, and then I thought,

1419.text: better keep an eye on you.

1429.text: You have just killed a man.

1433.text: I’ve seen men die before, and good men, friends of mine.

1445.text: They’re just both so tender and open with each other here. I, oh!

1455.text: You were gonna take the damned pill, weren’t you?

1503.text: And only a fool argues with his doctor.

1506.text: He needs to eat? Also, only a fool argues with his doctor? Really?

1512.text: The episode ends with them sharing a knowing look and walking off to dinner.

1522.text: Somewhere, in a parallel universe where none of us were fortunate enough to be born in,

1526.text: Sherlock and John have already been married for three years, have adopted a dog,

1529.text: and go out for romantic dinners every Friday night.

1531.text: (sigh) When will we be so lucky?

1533.text: So yes, the pilot isn’t as well done as the finished series,

1536.text: and it’s definitely a lot more blatant with the subtext,

1538.text: but that’s because the production team didn’t realize it was going to end up being such a huge phenomenon.

1542.text: Instead, they were just happy to make their cheesy romance that went under the radar.

1546.text: However, that isn't what we ended up getting, and in many ways I’m grateful for that.

1550.text: I certainly wouldn’t have so much to talk about if they continued the series from the pilot.

1553.text: But I think it’s important to appreciate the humble beginnings of BBC Sherlock.

1556.text: It reminds us that the creators don’t care about the ratings

1558.text: or creating something that everyone will love.

1560.text: They just want to share their version of Sherlock Holmes with whoever will enjoy it,

1562.text: and that centers around one key thing. The relationship between John and Sherlock.

1566.text: To close, here’s an interview question that Mark and Steven answered in 2010:

1569.text: 'The on-screen chemistry between Benedict and Martin is utterly phenomenal.

1573.text: Has it influenced your script writing, knowing that you have this chemistry to draw on? If so, how?

1578.text: Well, yes, it certainly informed it once we'd seen the pilot

1581.text: but great chemistry is actually great acting.

1583.text: We knew from the first moment they were in a room together that we had the show.'

1586.text: And even now that’s still the most important part.

1588.text: I hope you enjoyed the extra video this weekend, don’t expect it to happen too often.

1591.text: Thank you as always to Stacey for helping me with this,

1594.text: and for working double time to help me get two videos out in a row.

1596.text: As always, links to everything I've referenced can be found in the description below.

1599.text: I'm still deciding on the topic of the next video.

1601.text: If you have a topic you're really excited to see, leave your suggestions in the comments of the last video.

1605.text: In general I’m going to try to have these out once a week, so you'll see me again next weekend.

1609.text: Until then, get ready to believe.

1620.text: I'm actually filming these on the same day,

1622.text: I just changed my outfit and took off my glasses to trick you.

1626.text: So this is the exact same tea as I had a few minutes ago.

1629.text: Or, yesterday, for you, I guess.

1635.text: (laughing) It, it did go through a microwave, so it's warm again. That's nice.

1639.text: I kind of just want to put in some more coffee. Oh!!! That's right!!!

1648.text: Until then, get ready to believe!

1649.text: Tu du tu du tu du tu du tu du...
